overview_of_class:
Reading World Literature: "Self" Creation & First Person Narration
Beyond the grammatical, what is meant by the "first person"? Some answers might include a literary technique, a claim to identity, and a perspective on the world. Yet no matter how clear its vision, the story of an "I" also unfolds as a dark mystery, one that is never fully solved. From childhood on, how does the "I," with its own secret desires and ulterior motives, absorb or transfigure the environments that surround it ? its cultural, political, and physical geographies? How are the notions of reliability or self-knowledge anchored or imperiled by the mysteries, inventions, and confessions of first-person story-telling (especially as it draws on philosophy and poetry)? This course gives students concrete tools for reflecting on first person aesthetics, while always returning to larger questions about how the problem of perspective helps create or alienate a "self," in the struggle to solve the mystery (or even the crime) of identity.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Brief introductory lectures, seminar-style discussion, small group exercises

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Active participation, occasional posts to Canvas, written assignments (both creative and formal)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Readings will likely include:
Short selections from the writings of Marcel Proust, Walter Benjamin, Clarice Lispector
Yukio Mishima, Confessions of a Mask
Albert Camus, The Stranger
Kamel Daoud, The Meursault Investigation
Marilynn Robinson, Housekeeping
Mahmoud Darwish, Memory for Forgetfulness

Films will likely include:
Billy Wilder, Double Indemnity
Sarah Polley, Stories We Tell
